SVJedi can also be installed from Bioconda.

SVJedi is written in Python 3, it requires as input a set of SVs (VCF format), a reference genome (fasta format) picture(0,0)(-35,0)(1,0)30 (0,35)(0,-1)30 picture picture(0,0)(35,0)(-1,0)30 (0,35)(0,-1)30 picture "output" -2020/11/30 -page 4 -#4 picture(0,0)(-35,0)(1,0)30 (0,-35)(0,1)30 picture picture(0,0)(35,0)(-1,0)30 (0,-35)(0,1)30 picture and a sequencing read file (fastq or fasta format).
SVJedi was first compared to two tools, Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al., 2018) and svviz2 (Spies et al., 2015).
SVJedi, like the other tools, had more difficulties to accurately genotype small variants (<100 bp) and those located in large tandem repeat regions.
SVJedi accuracy and robustness were evaluated on simulated data of real deletions in a human chromosome.
SVJedi was assessed on simulated datasets on the human chromosome 1 (assembly GRCh37) based on real characterized deletions for the human genome.
SVJedi was applied on a real human dataset, from the individual HG002, son of the so-called Ashkenazi trio dataset.
SVJedi was applied on a real human ONT PromethION 44x dataset for the individual HG002 as well.
SVJedi was applied on a 30x PacBio long read dataset from individual HG002, to assess the genotypes of both deletions and insertions of this high confidence set.
SVJedi was applied on the same SV call set and for the same HG002 individual, but with sequencing data obtained by a different long read technology, namely Oxford Nanopore.
SVJedi was compared on the PacBio HG002 dataset to two other tools that can genotype a set of SVs with long read sequencing data, Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al., 2018) and svviz2 (Spies et al., 2015).

svviz2 is a visualisation tool enabling to visualize how reads align to the reference and alternative alleles of a given SV, as a byproduct it can estimate a genotype based on the aligned read counts.
svviz2 obtained the lowest genotyping accuracy (65.9 %, with a 10 % difference between deletions and insertions).

On the opposite, svviz2 obtained its best genotyping accuracy for the smallest SVs (<100 bp) and it rapidly drops for SVs larger than 250 bp, falling below 30 % for SV sizes between 1 kb and 10 kb.
Both Sniffles and pbsv analyses do not always predict SVs at the exact simulated coordinates, so a predicted SV is considered identical as the expected SV if both SVs overlap by at least 70 %.
We can observe that SVJedi has a better accuracy than Sniffles-Ivcf for all SV size classes.

To a lesser extend, Sniffles-Ivcf genotyping accuracy is also lower for large insertions than large deletions (69.6 % for insertions vs 85.7 % for deletions, ≥ 1 kb), whereas SVJedi genotyping accuracy is unaffected by SV type for all size classes.

The large runtime of svviz2 (more than 5 days) can be explained by the fact that it is not natively parallelized, when manually parallelized on 20 CPU (only 20 due to memory limits), it took roughly 11h.
All tools were run on a Linux 40-CPU node running at 2.60 GHz, all command lines are given in Supplementary Material Section 2.
Compared to other tools, SVJedi was the fastest among the tested ones (Table 2).

As shown in Table 2, both Sniffles-Ivcf and svviz2 have genotyping rates close to 100 % but at the expense of lower genotyping accuracies (detailed results for all genotypes are given in Supplementary Table 5).
The robustness of our tool, SVJedi, was highlighted in this work, for several sequencing depths and error rates, but also related to the precision of the breakpoint positions.

As expected, the accuracy of SVJedi increases with the read depth, but interestingly, even at low coverage (6x) the accuracy is on average above 94 % and a plateau is quickly reached between 20x and 30x, with already 97 % of genotyping accuracy at 20x.

With a 44x PromethION dataset, SVJedi shows very similar genotyping performances as with the PacBio dataset (90.7 % accuracy and 86.2 % rate, see Supplementary Table 4), highlighting its versatility with respect to long read sequencing technologies.
Among the long read genotypers, SVJedi was 7 times faster than Sniffles-Ivcf and 50 times faster than svviz2.

When comparing between SV types, svviz2 genotyping accuracy is significantly lower for insertions than deletions, with, in particular, less than 10 % of the insertions larger than 1 kb that are correctly genotyped (see Supplementary Figure 4).

Following long read technology's development, many SV discovery tools have emerged, such as Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al., 2018), NanoSV (Stancu et al., 2017), pbsv (unpublished) or SVIM (Heller and Vingron, 2019).
As expected, most inconsistent genotypes concern SVs that were genotyped differently between SVJedi and GiaB (48.7 %, n = 154), confirming for those that they are probably wrongly assessed by SVJedi.
This demonstrates the higher benefit of using long reads and a dedicated genotyping tool such as SVJedi rather than short reads.

Such genotyping methods already exist for short reads data (Alkan et al., 2011;Chander et al., 2019): for instance, SVtyper (Chiang et al., 2015), SV 2 (Antaki et al., 2017), Nebula (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/566620v1).

More precisely, among the assigned genotypes, there are 91.7 % of deletions and 92.5 % of insertions that are genotyped by SVJedi identically as the GiaB call set (the detailed contingency tables are provided in Supplementary Table 2).

We show that the genotyping accuracy with σ equals 50 bp does not fall below 94 % (see Supplementary Figure 3), indicating that SVJedi is not much impacted by the exact definition of the positions of the reference breakpoints.
SVJedi was compared on the PacBio HG002 dataset to two other tools that can genotype a set of SVs with long read sequencing data, Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al., 2018) and svviz2 (Spies et al., 2015).
We also compared our approach with two SV discovery tools, Sniffles again but in its default mode and Pacific Biosciences SV caller, pbsv 2 .

To our knowledge, there exist only two tools, that can perform genotyping with long read data for a given set of SVs, the discovery tool Sniffles with a specific option and the SV visualisation tool svviz2, but both are not purely dedicated to the genotyping task.
More surprisingly, for the discovered SVs, their genotyping accuracy is overall smaller than with other approaches, with 43.9 % and 78.9 % for Sniffles and pbsv respectively.

As a result, both tools obtained the lowest genotyping rates over all genotyping approaches: among the 12,745 SVs, only 6,127 were discovered by Sniffles, and 8,326 by pbsv (genotyping rates of 48.1 % and 65.3 % respectively, see Table 2 and details in Supplementary Table 5).

Since SVtyper does not support insertion variants, we focus here only  on deletions, and the 5,464 deletions from the GiaB call set were genotyped with SVtyper using a 2x250 bp 30x Illumina read dataset of HG002.
More surprisingly, for the discovered SVs, their genotyping accuracy is overall smaller than with other approaches, with 43.9 % and 78.9 % for Sniffles and pbsv respectively.

Following long read technology's development, many SV discovery tools have emerged, such as Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al., 2018), NanoSV (Stancu et al., 2017), pbsv (unpublished) or SVIM (Heller and Vingron, 2019).
Sniffles is a SV discovery tool that has an option (-Ivcf) enabling a genotyping mode instead of a discovery mode, we will thereafter refer to this tool usage as Sniffles-Ivcf.

As a result, both tools obtained the lowest genotyping rates over all genotyping approaches: among the 12,745 SVs, only 6,127 were discovered by Sniffles, and 8,326 by pbsv (genotyping rates of 48.1 % and 65.3 % respectively, see Table 2 and details in Supplementary Table 5).
SVJedi was compared on the PacBio HG002 dataset to two other tools that can genotype a set of SVs with long read sequencing data, Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al., 2018) and svviz2 (Spies et al., 2015).

To a lesser extend, Sniffles-Ivcf genotyping accuracy is also lower for large insertions than large deletions (69.6 % for insertions vs 85.7 % for deletions, ≥ 1 kb), whereas SVJedi genotyping accuracy is unaffected by SV type for all size classes.

A stratified analysis of the genotyping performances of all three tools with respect to the SV size is presented in Fig. 4. We can observe that SVJedi has a better accuracy than Sniffles-Ivcf for all SV size classes.
As expected, most inconsistent genotypes concern SVs that were genotyped differently between SVJedi and GiaB (48.7 %, n = 154), confirming for those that they are probably wrongly assessed by SVJedi.

To our knowledge, there exist only two tools, that can perform genotyping with long read data for a given set of SVs, the discovery tool Sniffles with a specific option and the SV visualisation tool svviz2, but both are not purely dedicated to the genotyping task.

Table 2 shows that more than half of the deletions are genotyped differently by SVtyper than in the high confidence GiaB call set, resulting in a genotyping accuracy of only 46.5 %, while this percentage rises to 91.7 % for SVJedi with long reads.
